results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 150
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Nearly everywhere today a major concern is cutting back on waste to help preserve resources. This film spots a few obvious, and a few very strange areas where intriguing new ways are being developed for reducing waste. Domestic waste; agricultural waste; transport waste; waste television space; cattle-feed research to improve milk production are shown.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 149
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Science has given time a different meaning - what was once the work of years is now achieved in days; days are reduced to seconds. Looks at a few of the developments which are helping to make this an instant world - computerised graphics; laser welding; portable landing fields equipment.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 148
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Examines contemporary attempts to predict and control the environmental effects of pollution. Details a study of how atmospheric carbon dioxide levels can alter human metabolism; redesigned cylinders which reduce the violent ignition noise from diesel engines; experimental batteries which replace lead and nickel with sulphur and sodium as their more benign principal components; and a pioneering facility for the safe storage and recuperation of toxic wastes.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 147
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Improved communications are the axles on which the wheels of progress turn. But in an age of television from the moon, there are still areas on earth where communications fail. Examines a few of the communication gaps - and the way they are being bridged.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 146
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Often being forced to rethink and see things in a different way can open up a vast avenue of approach to new ideas. Looks at recent developments of science in road safety, agriculture, health and aviation, which grew out of just this kind of rethinking.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 145
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Certain scientific developments have an immediate appeal - appeal based on their inherent elegance. Looks at four ideas in science: 1. Geodesic structures. 2. An umbrella to form a temporary seal on a punctured boat. 3. Specific drugs. 4. Linear electric motor for a weaving shuttle/loom or high speed trains.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 144
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: In spite of the complex controls of technology there are still areas where our control is lost - thousands of people die every year from disease, fire, accidents on the road. Highlights four areas - road safety, malaria research, radioactive therapy, and pneumatic fire fighting, where new developments are extending our control.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 143
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Man-made fibres impregnated with carbon, which conducts electric current so static charge can never build up are already being used in coal mines, where a spark can mean an explosion, and in the future they could be used for low power heating; detecting eye diseases early could save a lot of people a lot of sight; a new system allows patients to be tested for glaucoma quickly, effectively, and cheaply; a new type of fertiliser releases its goodness into the soil gradually - so it isn’t washed away in the first rain storm.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 141
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Concrete track: a new technique ensuring that rails do not move. The helicopter that flies upside down: its secret is a new rotor head made from titanium. Blind calculation: an electronic calculator for the blind reveals the figures in a series of audible pops and bleeps. Fire extinguisher system for cars: a harmless extinguishing gas is released into all compartments of the car.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 139
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Perpendicular architecture: a tent designed for mountaineers who spend their dormitory hours hanging from the vertical faces of mountains. Burns hoverbed: a new treatment for burns, a bed which supports the patient on air by the hover principle. Resins and foam: quick setting resins react with water to set hard; expanding foams fill potentially dangerous cracks in cable ducts, as part of a fire protection system for power stations.
